chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text:
$a)$ Because the company seems to have no debt, the weighted average cost of capital would represent the firm's cost of equity, also with the company, stock cash seems to be the only source of funding.

Therefore, the cost of equity capital is $\boxed{9.4\%}$

$b)$ Second, we have to find out the cost of equity which we denote with $CE$, where the cost of equity capital $C$ is $9.4\%$, debt $D$ is $6.1\%$, debt ration $DR$ is $0.25$, equity ratio $ER$ is $0.75$ and the tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$

$$\begin{align*}
CE&=C+(C-D) \times \frac{DR}{ER} \times (1-TR)\\[12pt]
&=9.4\%+(9.4\%-6.1\%) \times \frac{0.25}{0.75} \times (1-21\%)\\[12pt]
&=0.094+(0.094-0.061) \times \frac{0.25}{0.75} \times (1-0.21)\\[12pt]
&=0.094+(0.033) \times 0.33 \times (1-0.21)\\[12pt]
&=0.094+(0.033) \times 0.33 \times 0.79\\[12pt]
&=0.094+0.008603\\[12pt]
&=0.1026\\[7pt]
&=10.26\%

\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the cost of equity is $\boxed{10.26\%}$

$c)$ Third, we have to find out the cost of equity which we denote with $CE$, where the cost of equity capital $C$ is $9.4\%$, debt $D$ is $6.1\%$, debt ration $DR$ is $0.5$, equity ratio $ER$ is $0.5$ and the tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$

$$\begin{align*}
CE&=C+(C-D) \times \frac{DR}{ER} \times (1-TR)\\[12pt]
&=9.4\%+(9.4\%-6.1\%) \times \frac{0.5}{0.5} \times (1-21\%)\\[12pt]
&=0.094+(0.094-0.061) \times \frac{0.5}{0.5} \times (1-0.21)\\[12pt]
&=0.094+(0.033) \times 1 \times (1-0.21)\\[12pt]
&=0.094+(0.033) \times 1\times 0.79\\[12pt]
&=0.094+0.02607\\[12pt]
&=0.12\\[7pt]
&=12\%

\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the cost of equity is $\boxed{12\%}$

$d)$ Fourth, we have to find out the weighted average cost of capital of option $b$ which we denote with $WA$, where the weight of equity $WE$ is $75\%$, cost of equity $CE$ is $10.26\%$, debt ratio $DR$ is $25\%$, debt $D$ is $6.1\%$ and the tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$

$$\begin{align*}
WA&=(WE \times CE)+\biggl(DR \times D \times (1-TR)\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=(75\% \times 10.26\%)+\biggl(25\% \times 6.1\% \times (1-21\%)\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=(0.75 \times 0.1026)+\biggl(0.25 \times 0.061 \times (1-0.21)\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=(0.07695)+\biggl(0.25 \times 0.061 \times 0.79\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=0.07695 + 0.01204\\[7pt]
&=0.0889\\[7pt]
&=8.89\%

\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the weighted average cost of capital of option $b$ is $\boxed{8.89\%}$

We have to find out the weighted average cost of capital of option $c$ which we denote with $WA$, where the weight of equity $WE$ is $50\%$, cost of equity $CE$ is $12\%$, debt ratio $DR$ is $50\%$, debt $D$ is $6.1\%$ and the tax rate $TR$ is $21\%$

$$\begin{align*}
WA&=(WE \times CE)+\biggl(DR \times D \times (1-TR)\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=(50\% \times 12\%)+\biggl(50\% \times 6.1\% \times (1-21\%)\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=(0.5 \times 0.12)+\biggl(0.5 \times 0.061 \times (1-0.21)\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=(0.06)+\biggl(0.5 \times 0.061 \times 0.79\biggl)\\[7pt]
&=0.06 + 0.024095\\[7pt]
&=0.0840\\[7pt]
&=8.40\%

\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the weighted average cost of capital of option $c$ is $\boxed{8.40\%}$
